Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Planetary Geomorphology -- the 45th Annual Binghamton Geomorphology Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this work is to support the 45th Binghamton Geomorphology Symposium on planetary geomorphology. The systematic exploration of our Solar System provides for substantive and insightful comparison among its various geologic bodies, including Earth. This symposium will lead to significant integration of the closely related fields of terrestrial and planetary geomorphology. Inclusion of the terrestrial geomorphology community in analyzing and understanding extraterrestrial data leverages NASA investment in planetary exploration for the benefit of terrestrial geomorphology. Terrestrial geomorphologists will be exposed to both an historical overview of and cutting-edge research within the planetary community and will form contacts with their planetary colleagues, who will benefit from terrestrial geomorphologists expertise in 'ground-truth.' The invited scholars represent the full range of academic ranks, from graduate students to senior professors. Live streaming of the oral presentations and public access to the digital archive will greatly enhance participation and accessibility for foreign professionals and students, including undergraduates.

Spacecraft missions to other planetary bodies are now providing surface data at resolutions equal to or better than those of terrestrial data, presenting an opportunity for new discoveries in geomorphology. This symposium will convene geomorphologists from both the terrestrial and extraterrestrial communities across a range of subdisciplines (impact, tectonics, volcanic, aeolian, fluvial, glacial and periglacial, lacustrine, flood) relevant to the discipline of planetary geomorphology. The goals and scope of the work to be accomplished are the communication and synthesis of ideas between terrestrial and planetary geomorphologists from the relevant academic subdisciplines. The methods and approaches to be used are the presentation and discussion of analyses of these terrestrial and extraterrestrial data and their geomorphologic implications. Publication of invited papers in Geomorphology will also provide broad access to ideas presented at the symposium.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT                                              

Overview of activity

 Spacecraft missions to other planetary bodies are continuing to provide surface data at unprecedented resolutions, which in some cases are equal to or better than the resolution of data for the Earth.  Particularly in combination with remote sensing data of earth, the data from these extraterrestrial missions represent a new era in geomorphology.  The systematic exploration of our Solar System provides for substantive and insightful comparison among the geologic bodies in our Solar System, including Earth. 

 The purpose of the activity of the 45th Binghamton Geomorphology Symposium in Planetary Geomorphology, held in Sept 12-14, 2014 hosted by the University of Tennessee-Knoxville, was to convene geomorphologists from both the terrestrial and planetary communities to discuss the range of subdisciplines (impact, tectonics, volcanic, aeolian, fluvial, glacial and periglacial, lacustrine, flood) within the field of planetary geomorphology.  The presentations included both case studies focusing on extraterrestrial geomorphology as well as studies using terrestrial analogs.  In addition, the symposium presented information on readily available planetary datasets and analysis tools, to support increased involvement of the terrestrial community in the analysis of extraterrestrial data. 

 Intellectual merit

The 45th Binghamton Geomorphology Symposium enabled and facilitated communication of ideas among geomorphologists housed in a range of different academic departments (e.g., geography, geology, civil engineering, environmental sciences).  This communication occurred through oral and poster presentations over the range of subdisciplines of planetary geomorphology. The publications associated with the 11 invited oral presentations were published in 2015 in a special issue of the international peer-reviewed journal Geomorphology.

 Broader impacts

The invited scholars represented the full range of academic ranks, from graduate students to senior professors.  Young researchers (postdoctoral associates and graduate students) gave invited presentations both orally and in the interactive poster session.  Contributed posters were also actively sought. Publication of the invited papers in Geomorphology provided broad access to ideas presented at the symposium.


Last Modified: 08/31/2015
Modified by: Devon M Burr
